cards.title: Athletics / Jason Gardener sad at study finding children think video games are exercise
cards.rawTitle: Jason Gardener sad at study finding children think video games are exercise

item.title: Jason Gardener sad at study finding children think video games are exercise
item.trailText: The former Olympic gold-winning sprinter expressed concerned following a Youth Sport Trust report which found one in four children believe playing video games counts as exercise
item.standFirst:
• Former sprinter concerned following Youth Sport Trust report
• One in four children believe playing video games counts as exercise
item.body:
The former Great Britain sprinter Jason Gardener said it is sad and concerning that one in four children believe playing video games counts as exercise.

Related: School sport suffers as one in four children think video games are exercise, says report

Research released this week by the Youth Sport Trust, the charitable organisation that coordinates school sport, warned that the sector is at a crossroads, 10 years after London was awarded the 2012 Olympics amid much talk of legacy.

The new report – Class of 2035 – discussed the potential ramifications technology could have on future youth participation and school sport in the next 20 years, and Gardener warned that further work is needed to educate children about the benefits of physical activity rather than video technology.

Gardener, speaking as an ambassador for the YST’s School Sport Week at St Katharine’s primary in Bournemouth, said: “It’s really concerning, if that’s what they perceive to be sport, and sad. Technology, digital technology, has transformed lives and can give us a massive quality difference. We find phones and tablets very useful.

“But we’ve got to make sure kids still have the opportunity to come outside in the fresh air and have fun, to keep obesity away. It’s [obesity] something that is at an all-time high and we are not being responsible – we need to educate children and parents as to the benefits of doing sport and PE, of eating healthy food and having an active lifestyle.”

A separate YST report earlier in the year found that the average number of minutes schoolchildren were participating in PE had fallen below two hours a week. Meanwhile the new sports minister, Tracey Crouch, has promised to rethink a new, unified sport policy following disappointing participation figures released by Sport England earlier this month.

Gardener, who won Olympic gold in the 4x100m relay at Athens 2004, added: “More PE is a no-brainer, you’ve got to make it happen. Physical activity increases performance in the classroom.”

cards.title: Rugby league / Australia coach Tim Sheens to become director of rugby at Salford
cards.rawTitle: Australia coach Tim Sheens to become director of rugby at Salford

item.title: Australia coach Tim Sheens to become director of rugby at Salford
item.trailText: Australia’s national coach Tim Sheens has agreed to take up the role of director of rugby of Salford, the owner has revealed
item.standFirst:
• ‘I hope he will be with us in a week,’ says owner
• Coach won 26 of his 31 Tests at Kangaroos
item.body:
Australia’s national coach Tim Sheens has agreed to take up the role of director of rugby of Salford, the owner Marwan Koukash has revealed.

The 64-year-old Sheens spent a month with the Red Devils working in an advisory role earlier this year and will now return in a formal capacity.

“The club have agreed to appoint Tim Sheens as director of rugby,” Koukash told a press conference at the AJ Bell Stadium, which was attended by around 120 fans.

“I hope he will be with us in a week or so. I need Tim’s help to ensure we recruit the right people to this club.”

With his 12-month contract set to expire at the end of this year, and with Australia not playing a Test match until the mid-season match against the Kiwis next year, Sheens’ seven-year stint as Kangaroos coach looks to be over.

Sheens has had a historic tenure, highlighted by Australia’s dominance during their 2013 World Cup success and only Bob Fulton, with 40 Tests, has coached Australia more times. Sheens won 26 of his 31 Tests in control, although the Kangaroos have lost their past three games against the Kiwis.

Sheens began his coaching career at Penrith in 1984 and also held roles at Canberra, North Queensland and Wests Tigers, where he last coached up to 2012.

He was appointed coach of New South Wales’ State of Origin team in 1991 and succeeded Ricky Stuart as the Kangaroos coach after the 2008 World Cup final defeat by New Zealand.

Koukash said Sheens would initially be at the club until the end of the season but he expected him to remain in the post long-term.

He emphasised that the appointment did not affect the position of Iestyn Harris as head coach and denied a role had been offered to the former Great Britain scrum-half Bobbie Goulding.

“Obviously to start with Tim is on a short-term contract until the end of the season but it wouldn’t surprise me if he stayed on for two more years after that,” Koukash said.

“He will help the club in many ways. I want to invest in youth and I need Tim’s help to ensure we recruit the players who will be proud to play for the club.

“Iestyn Harris is still the head coach. He has worked with Tim Sheens before and Tim’s appointment has no bearing on Harris’s position.”

cards.title: Snooker / Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
cards.rawTitle: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match

item.title: Ronnie O’Sullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
item.trailText: Ronnie O’Sullivan has claimed he was offered money to throw a snooker match but turned it down as the risk was not worth taking
item.standFirst:
• Five-times world champion says the risk is not worth taking
• Stephen Lee’s 12-year ban has scared a lot of players, he adds
item.body:
Ronnie O’Sullivan, the five-times world snooker champion, has said he was offered money to throw a match but declined.

Speaking on The Clare Balding Show, which will air on BT Sport and BBC Two this week, O’Sullivan claimed other players did accept bribes in the past but said he believed the problem had been eradicated after Stephen Lee was banned for match-fixing.

O’Sullivan said: “I was offered money once to throw a game but I couldn’t do it. It’s your sport, you love your sport. They smell it anyway. The risk is just not worth taking and I couldn’t live with myself if I got involved in that.”

In 2012 Lee was suspended on match-fixing charges and the former world No5 was subsequently handed a 12-year ban.

Related: Stephen Lee banned from snooker for 12 years for seven match-fixing charges

“I don’t think it’ll go on in snooker any more because they really made an example of Stephen Lee,” O’Sullivan added. “They banned him for 12 years and I think a lot of the guys that were at it, they’re thinking they wouldn’t be able to play snooker ever again.

“So I think it’s been stamped out of snooker now and if anyone was to do it, they know what the consequences are.”

Three weeks ago, the Irish amateur John Sutton was banned for six years after the sport’s world governing body found him guilty of match-fixing and misusing inside information.

The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association said Sutton’s offences related to suspicious betting on his match against Scotland’s Jamie Burnett in the qualifying stages of the International Championship.

cards.title: US sports / Man takes amazing one-handed catch while bottle-feeding baby at Cubs game
cards.rawTitle: Man takes amazing one-handed catch while bottle-feeding baby at Cubs game

item.title: Man takes amazing one-handed catch while bottle-feeding baby at Cubs game
item.trailText: A Cubs fan bottle-feeding a baby made a great barehanded catch over the glove of the Dodgers first baseman Adrian Gonzalez
item.standFirst:
• Cubs fan takes ball over glove of Dodgers first baseman Adrian Gonzalez
• Dodgers complain about interference as fan prevents out
item.body:
A Cubs fan who was bottle-feeding a baby made a casual barehanded catch, almost stealing the ball out of the glove of the Dodgers first baseman Adrian Gonzalez on Tuesday night.

The Cubs had two out and none on base in the second inning at Wrigley Field when Jason Hammel fouled off a pitch from Zack Greinke. Gonzalez chased the popup and reached over a rolled-up tarpaulin while trying to make a play. But the fan, Keith Hartley, reached out and grabbed the ball with his right hand while carrying his baby Isaac in his left arm, while the child was suckling on a bottle.

“I was just trying to protect him,” said Hartley. “I see the ball coming up and it just kinda fell in my hand. It’s not quite the World Series so hopefully Adrian’s not too upset. He’s on my fantasy team.”

But Gonzalez said after the game: “It would have been more impressive if the baby would have caught it.”

The first-base umpire and crew chief Jerry Meals originally ruled the play a foul ball out of play, but the Dodgers manager Don Mattingly came out of the dugout and argued for fan interference. After a short delay, the call was reversed and Hammel was ruled out, ending the inning.

After the game but the Cubs manager Joe Maddon added: “That was outstanding. You worry about the baby, of course, but it looked like he had it under control. It looked like he did it before, almost. That was a great play.”

cards.title: Australia sport / Brumbies' Henry Speight out of Super Rugby semi-final with five-week ban
cards.rawTitle: Brumbies' Henry Speight out of Super Rugby semi-final with five-week ban

item.title: Brumbies' Henry Speight out of Super Rugby semi-final with five-week ban
item.trailText: The Brumbies winger Henry Speight has been banned for five weeks for dangerous play and will miss this weekend’s Super Rugby semi-final against the Hurricanes
item.standFirst:
• Decision to send off winger last weekend upheld by judiciary
  • Wallaby also out of Australia’s Rugby Championship opener
item.body:
The Brumbies winger Henry Speight has been banned for five weeks for dangerous play and will miss this weekend’s Super Rugby semi-final against the Wellington Hurricanes.

Speight was shown a red card for slamming Juan de Jongh head-first into the ground at a ruck in the 74th minute of the Canberra-based outfit’s stunning victory over South Africa’s Stormers last weekend.

The Wallabies winger had already been found guilty of the offence by a judicial hearing but the Brumbies were given a glimmer of hope that he might escape a ban when officials requested more information before handing down the punishment.

“After taking all relevant facts into consideration, I found that the referee’s decision to issue a red card was correct,” SANZAR’s judicial officer said in his decision. “The tackle caused De Jongh’s feet to lift and his head to make contact with the ground first.

“It was not a legitimate clean out at a ruck and the player was fortunate not to have been injured. An aggravating factor is the ongoing need for a deterrent for dangerous play such as this which carries with it the real risk of serious injury.”

Speight’s ban means he will also miss Australia’s opening match of the Rugby Championship against South Africa in Brisbane on 18 July.

Brumbies prop Scott Sio said the team would undoubtedly miss the hulking Fiji-born winger. “Especially with the calibre of player he is, he adds such a lot to the team, not just in attack but in his defensive awareness as well,” he said in Canberra before the verdict was announced.

“We lose a lot there, but the best thing about our squad is that we’ve got guys like Robbie Coleman, James Dargaville, Nigel Ah Wong, Lausii Taliauli, who all add something different if they are called upon to replace Henry.”

With their other winger Joe Tomane on fire after a hat-trick against the Stormers last week, it is in defence that the Brumbies will miss Speight most. If Speight had escaped a ban, he would have been responsible for marking All Blacks left winger Julian “The Bus” Savea on Saturday.

Coleman would be the most obvious replacement on the right wing but while the 24-year-old has no shortage of pace, he gives up 20 kg in weight and 14 cm in height to Savea.

displayImages.credit: Gallo Images/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Speight was on the receiving end of a red card against the Stormers at DHL Newlands Stadium last weekend.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Gallo Images/Getty Images

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
cards.rawTitle: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa

item.title: GB women one win from securing Olympic spot after sinking South Africa
item.trailText: Alex Danson hailed a ‘really professional performance’ by Great Britain after their 2-0 win over South Africa
item.standFirst:
• Reading striker Alex Danson gives Great Britain 12th-minute lead
• Ireland suffer 4-3 World League shootout defeat by China
item.body:
Great Britain’s women are one win away from Olympic qualification after a fifth successive victory at the World League tournament in Valencia.

Two goals in the opening 14 minutes were enough to beat South Africa 2-0. The victory took them into the World League final in Argentina in December but, more importantly, a top-three finish in this tournament will guarantee a spot at the Rio 2016 Games.

The Reading striker Alex Danson scored her third goal of the competition with a clever spin and shot in the 12th minute and then her club-mate Kate Richardson-Walsh’s deflected penalty corner flew in off the underside of the crossbar.

“We are absolutely delighted. It was a really professional performance by the team,” Danson said. “I think the work we do back home puts us in a good position here; fitness is a key thing and we still have a lot left in the legs.”

Great Britain will face the winners of Germany against Spain in Saturday’s semi-final.

Ireland’s hopes of securing automatic Olympic qualification for the first time were cruelly dashed in a 4-3 shootout defeat by China.

Having conceded an early goal, Ireland deservedly equalised through Chloe Watkins with 18 minutes to go and they were denied a winner when Megan Frazer’s goal was disallowed after an umpire’s video referral.

Ayeisha McFerran was put in goal for the shootout and made two saves but, when Nicola Evans missed the chance to win on the last of the five regulation attempts they lost out in the second round of sudden death.

Ireland’s diminishing hopes of reaching Brazil next year rest with them finishing fifth and hoping results at other qualifying competitions later this year go their way.

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage 9
item.trailText: The best pictures from the ninth and final leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lorient in France to Gothenburg in Sweden, via a 24 hour pit stop in The Hague. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and visits 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months. The overall winners were Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, finishing 24 minutes ahead of second-placed Team Brunel.• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the ninth and final leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lorient in France to Gothenburg in Sweden, via a 24 hour pit stop in The Hague. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and visits 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months. The overall winners were Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, finishing 24 minutes ahead of second-placed Team Brunel.

• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race

snap.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage 9 – in pictures

image.caption: The teams start from Lorient, France Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: The teams start from Lorient, France
image.cleanCaption: The teams start from Lorient, France
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from Lorient Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from Lorient
image.cleanCaption: A jumper leaves the Dongfeng Race Team during the start from Lorient
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ainhoa Sanchez/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg
image.cleanCaption: The fleet head to The Hague, then Gothenburg
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: After a quick start out of Lorient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: After a quick start out of Lorient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel
image.cleanCaption: After a quick start out of Lorient and a ‘tour de France’ through the Bay of Quiberon, the fleet then begins the 600 mile trek up the coast, around Brest, and into the Channel
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the Channel, all within close proximity of one another. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the English Channel, all within close proximity. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline
image.cleanCaption: Onboard Team Alvimedica. Free from the Bay of Biscay the fleet rounds Brest on the way to the Channel, all within close proximity of one another. Will Oxley looks at the on-deck nav screen while navigating the busy French coastline
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Amory Ross/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: Jens Dolmer and Louis Balcaen try and make up time after Team Brunel dropped from 1st to 7th within one hour due to a breakdown caused by weed on the keel, near the coast of Bretagne Photograph: Stefan Coppers/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Stefan Coppers/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Jens Dolmer and Louis Balcaen try and make up time after Team Brunel dropped from 1st to 7th within one hour due to a breakdown caused by weed on the keel, near the coast of Bretagne
image.cleanCaption: Jens Dolmer and Louis Balcaen try and make up time after Team Brunel dropped from 1st to 7th within one hour due to a breakdown caused by weed on the keel, near the coast of Bretagne
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Stefan Coppers/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
